awd_titl_txt: Assessing the Costs and Benefits of Cultural Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
In some societies, traditional marriage customs may produce brides and grooms under the age of 18. International development groups refer to these as "child marriages" and consider them to be damaging to well-being, particularly for girls. Therefore, with wide support from Western nations, including the United States, significant resources are invested in campaigns to eradicate these practices. However, this movement has also been critiqued for relying on a notion that there is a clear and absolute boundary between childhood and adulthood that lies at 18 years. In fact, there is surprisingly little objective information available about why "child marriage" remains prevalent in some places despite its purported harmful consequences. The research supported by this award will address this question. Results from the project will support policy recommendations, and contribute to a wider critical engagement with the notion that early transitions to adulthood are necessarily harmful in all circumstances. 

Research will be carried out in north western Tanzania among a Sukuma population where around one-third of girls marry before 18 years. Data collection will take place within a demographic surveillance site managed by the Tanzanian National Institute of Medical Research. Taking a mixed-methods approach, qualitative and quantitative data will be collected over a two-year period. To build an understanding of early marriage grounded in ethnographic reality, rather than stereotype, the project will first utilize focus group discussions and in-depth interviews to identify perceived risks to wellbeing that characterize female adolescence and the role of early marriage in elevating or mitigating such risk. Multiple dimensions of female wellbeing (physical and mental health, education, food security, empowerment, and community respect) will then be assessed via a large quantitative survey, and analyzed to determine if 18 years emerges as a meaningful threshold demarcating harmful marriage, or whether alternative age categorizations, if any, better predict variation in wellbeing. Quantitative and qualitative data will then be used test the hypotheses that early marriage is either the product of parental coercion and a parent-offspring conflict of interests, or whether it is better understood as a parental strategy to enhance the success of daughters. Finally, the project will quantify associations between age at menarche, first reproduction and marriage to explore hypothesized links between physiological and behavioral transitions into adulthood. The project includes the mentorship of an American Postdoctoral Scholar, research experience opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, and capacity building for longer-term international collaborative research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Global health agencies, including those based in the United States, increasing target the abolishment of 'child marriage' - marriage under 18 years, mainly affecting adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) in global south countries. Despite a growing number of interventions, few studies have explicitly differentiated and tested alternative theories for why ostensibly harmful early marriages occur. As such understanding of early marriage has been mired by stereotypes, stifling both theory development and the production of effective and culturally-sensitive policy. This project addressed this gap by conducting a case study of early marriage among a rural population in Mwanza, Tanzania, where female marriage under 18 years is common. Conducted research drew on anthropological theory of marriage and life course transitions, and a combination of quantitative data on women's wellbeing and marriage histories, and qualitative data on community perceptions of the perceived costs, benefits and drivers of early marriage. 

Results reveal a plurality in the drivers of marital transitions, even within the same community, delimiting three distinct scenarios. First, many AGYW, marry early in order to achieve relative social and economic security, and do so with encouragement and support from their parents. Such marriages may represent the best available option when situated among locally feasible alternatives. Secondly, some AGYW marry early to support their natal kin, but at a cost to themselves; which parents may encourage or resist. This scenario is consistent with presently dominant ideas of child marriage being driven by a 'parent-offspring conflict' of interests. However, our results make clear that such marriages are typically entered willingly by AGYW in this context, knowingly putting their own individual needs second to their wider family. Finally, a subset of marriages appear driven by attraction to men offering immediate economic and social benefits, which ultimately fail to provide stability and security for women in the long-term. These marriages frequently end in separation and are retroactively labelled bad decisions by women. Parents of daughters are particularly wary of such marriages, which may require elopement - again countering the dominant view that parents are key drivers of early marriage for AGYW. These findings add to anthropological scholarship on marriage and childhood, and have led to novel recommendations for global health actors dedicated to child marriage.  

The project also produced publications on common and important misunderstandings of the term child marriage, both among the study community in Tanzania and among the American public (assessed via an online survey). While many Tanzanian AGYW had heard of child marriage, the concept was routinely conflated with forced marriage, which is rare in the community, and non-marital teenage sex and pregnancy, which are common. As a likely consequence, participants disagreed on whether or not child marriage occurs locally. We also reveal that the American public tend to misinterpret the term child marriage as indicative of much earlier ages at marriage (e.g. <15 years), to substantially overestimate its global prevalence, and generally assume that marriage under 18 years is illegal in the USA, despite it being illegal in only 4/50 US states. We conclude that organizations seeking to empower women by reducing child marriage should be cautious of these misunderstandings, and wary of the potential for their own activities to seed misinformation.

Overall, the project has advanced interdisciplinary discussion and synthesis, integrating knowledge and methods from different branches of anthropology, population/global health and development studies. Specifically, we add to tradition of anthropological critique with respect to the implementation of international human rights and the categorization of 'harmful cultural practices' within global health. Several anthropologists have previously raised critiques of externally drawn boundaries of childhood with respect to categories adjacent to the 'child bride', such as 'child laborer' or 'child solider'. Building off these critiques, our project provides a much-needed counterpoint to the dominant and ethnocentric humanitarian discourse on child marriage. The project also contributes a novel case study to the nascent field of 'applied evolutionary anthropology', a fast-growing area where anthropologists are engaging with the policy implications of their research to support the people with whom they work.

The project included the mentorship of an American Postdoctoral Scholar, research experience opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, and capacity building for longer-term international collaborative research with contributing Tanzanian social scientists (based at the National Institute for Medical Research in Mwanza, Tanzania). Conclusions have been disseminated in a series of journal publications and blog articles, including a review paper contrasting findings from this Tanzanian context to wider literature on early marriage across the world.
